name: Minted to Skinted: Romantic Dinners for Every Budget

text.text: Minted to Skinted: Romantic Dinners for Every Budget

No matter who you're boning these days, you can't avoid the inevitable pull of date night. Maybe it's a milestone in your relaish' or maybe you're getting to know someone new; perhaps you need to relight the fire or make amends; or maybe you're just in the mood to woo. Either way you can't beat a proper tête-à-tête over dinner. 

Whatever your spending power, take a leaf out of our well-worn book of dating with one of these eateries: all charming, authentic and primed for a good old-fashioned romancing. We're making memories here people, so let's get this right.
** MINTED **

tip.text:
Kitty Fisher's is that impressive neighbourhood restaurant in a neighbourhood where nobody really lives. Pay a visit to this intimate, dimly-lit restaurant with an air of Victorian dining room about it for an ever-changing menu of British and Spanish fusion dishes that might dent your wallet but are sure to impress your tastebuds.

If you're really living the good life, grab a seat out front with your miniature poodle, and bask in the joy of London.

text.text:
Kitty Fisher's is that impressive neighbourhood restaurant in a neighbourhood where nobody really lives. It feels luxurious whilst also being intimate, dimly lit and cosy; and its ever-changing menu of British and Spanish fusion dishes will dent your wallet and your heart. Just as gorgeous as the restaurant itself, each dish is a little piece of art: luxurious flavours balanced to perfection. 

The damage: upwards of £80 (we've given you ballpark figures for two people before drinks).

tip.text:
Any self-respecting ‘Restaurants to Visit’ hitlist is gonna have the name Noble Rot somewhere on it, including ours. Discreetly tucked down Lamb’s Conduit Street in Bloomsbury, this is the golden egg of evening haunts: a cosy, laid-back wine bar and restaurant suitable for the informal and formal; group dines or intimate meals; quick drinks or long, leisurely gorges.

It’s about great French wine (and lots of it), great British food and great schmoozy ambience: where you’ll roll in for a glass of £4 wine at 7pm, before its magic takes hold and you end up downstairs in the rustic bistro-style restaurant at a quarter to midnight, suitably merry and full bellied. Let the amiable waiters take care of your wining needs because the list is extensive; and if hunger strikes (and your budget allows) head mouth first into bits like lamb saddle, braised Cornish turbot and roast guinea fowl. This is how it’s done.

text.text:
Discreetly tucked down Lamb’s Conduit Street in Bloomsbury, this is the golden egg of evening haunts: a cosy, laid-back wine bar and restaurant suitable for informal dinners and romancing alike. The wine list is mighty important here so you'll be hard-pressed to escape without spending a good chunk of your holiday fund, but the fine French fare, amiable waiters and grateful gaze of your loved one should make it worth it. 

The damage: upwards of £70 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
The third venue from the Old Spike Roastery lot, Aside is salivate central. Much as we wanted to stand by the kitchen door and watch each dish come out we weren't allowed. All joking aside, the menu really is summin'. It's small, seasonal and well curated, like a boutique festival. You can never be sure what's on the cards for your evening but think smoked eel croquettes, burrata with fennel and peach, or cod with mushrooms and corn. And the odd tasty curveball - goat curry?

They do a mighty good brunch 'ere too. We had a rustic and wholesome full English to make any farmhouse kitchen proud. Maybe you should make the time to get to know this little nugget, with an ice cold martini in hand of course.

text.text:
Hidden down a residential street in Peckham, Aside feels like a bit of hidden gem. Inside it's slick and stylish and salivate central. The menu really is summin', though you can never be too sure what's on the cards. Think smoked eel croquettes, burrata with fennel and peach, or cod with mushrooms and corn - all brought to you with effortless cool.

The damage: upwards of £60 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
Hidden away behind the red brick walls of a converted school - surrounded by a bouncy green lawn, fruit trees and other shrubbery - this restaurant is a pretty magical place: it makes you feel like you're in on a secret. Margot Henderson, the culinary smarts of the operation, cooked in some of the top London restaurants before setting up this little nugget, turning bike sheds into a soothing retreat from the Shoreditch madness. Decor is a thoughtful, modern kind of 'farmhouse chic' with pristine pine furniture and battered straw hats hanging along one wall.

Food - though heavenly - appears similarly effortless: think perfectly seasoned chicken pie, hunks of fuss-free fish and mounds of fresh leaves from the garden. It's the kind of place where lightly stewed plums come with huge sticky-centred meringues and helpings of cream so generous they would have Tom Kerridge in sweats. This is proper nostalgic British cooking - and we bloody love it.

text.text:
Behind the red brick walls of a converted school - surrounded by a bouncy green lawn, fruit trees and other shrubbery - Margot Henderson's cult restaurant is a pretty magical place. Food is heavenly: think perfectly seasoned chicken pie, hunks of fuss-free fish and mounds of fresh leaves grown in the garden. It's laid-back luxury topped with a buttery crust.

The damage: upwards of £60 (for two pre booze).
***PLAYING IT SAFE***

tip.text:
From the clever sorts behind Sager + Wilde, Fare Bar + Canteen is a damn nice place to eat, drink and while away as much time as you can manage or afford. Split on two levels in a fairly vast space, there's a relaxed bar and cafe area upstairs and a subterranean dining den beneath, with all the white walls, green leaves and alluring lighting you'll need for an intimate dine. The Old Street hustle outside fades out of memory as soon as you enter.

The day is on the chilled, cafe tip, but we came in after-dark, joining a well-heeled crowd in salivating over a Middle Eastern-inspired menu. From a crispy-on-the-outside, creamy-on-the-inside Jerusalem artichoke with crispy sage and capers; to a refreshingly sweet and subtle take on the tagine with braised beef shin and impossibly sweet heritage carrots, chestnuts, cracked siyez and dill, everything we ate was distinct, artful, and supremely tasty. The kind of eating where no words will pass between you and your fellow feeders - just squinting eyes of pleasure and a vigorously nodding nut.

The wine list is, as you’d expect from the Sager + Wild fam, high-end and high-pleasure, whilst carefully put-together, original cocktails will also demand your attention and wallet. All in all, a fantastic shout for a special, transportive eating experience.

text.text:
Fare Bar + Canteen combines a relaxed bar and cafe upstairs with a sultry subterranean dining den beneath, complete with all the alluring lighting you could need for an intimate dine. Come in after-dark for a Middle Eastern-inspired menu of small plates and hearty beef shin tagines. A high-end wine list and inventive cocktails will steal your heart... and wallet too.

The damage: upwards of £50 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
You might think your love story is cute, but did it produce a top-quality neighbourhood restaurant known far and wide for its inventive food at wallet-friendly prices? No, but this one did: Margaux and Joe - who met while they were both working at Trinity in Clapham - took their penchant for fine food to the streets of Brixton when it was rapidly gentrifying in 2015. The result is Naughty Piglets, a laid back bistro with dishes that are anything but.

Here you'll find modern European small plates and an epic wine list. The menu is seasonal and constantly evolving, but if you happen to catch it, the Korean style BBQ pork belly served with a chilli miso dip is killer. And the relaxed prices mean you'll have money left over for dessert, which is always bang on - think chocolate mousse with salted peanut praline. Win-win-win.

text.text:
You might think your love story is cute, but did it produce a top-quality neighbourhood restaurant? Naughty Piglets is the happy result of the meeting of Margaux and Joe who took their penchant for fine food and fine wine to the streets of Brixton, forming a laid-back bistro with dishes that are anything but. The menu is delicious, seasonal and constantly evolving - just like your relationship. 

The damage: upwards of £50 (for two pre booze).

tip.text: A stalwart of old Soho, Andrew Edmunds is usually busy with regulars and the odd lucky-striking tourist. Inside the feeling is wooden and rickety but the food shows no signs of falling behind - for starters the likes of burrata served with almonds caught our eye and for mains, the roast quail with charred aubergine, pomegranate and mint added a touch of Middle Eastern flavour to an otherwise very British establishment.

text.text:
Andrew Edmunds is that spot in Soho that you've walked past 100 times and said, 'Ooo that looks nice, let's go there next time'. Well now's the time, stud. Let the flicker of the candles in the window draw you in, while the modern British menu with a touch of Middle Eastern flavour seals the deal. Excellent food, perfect lighting, and the homeliest of atmospheres makes this an ideal date spot.

The damage: upwards of £40 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
If you thought Bun House had winning interiors, then just wait till you set foot in Tea Room just below. The retro Cantonese design continues but the tiling, neon signage and attention to detail is ramped up a notch. We perused the drinks menu printed on a vintage-looking newspaper and pretended we were hedonistic businessmen in 60s Hong Kong. The cocktails may be pricey but with damn good reason; ours was made with toasted maple infused baijiu, smoked tea liqueur, a lapsang tea smoked century pear and five spices. Some real grown up flavours.

With lots of small bites you can try all sorts without completely breaking the bank - be it perfectly spiced lamb shoulder skewers, the most refreshing prickly cucumbers or rich duck tongue fries. We thoroughly enjoyed the way their clay pot dishes crisped up beautifully at the bottom for a many textured rice topped with a subtly flavoured tea egg. For full immersion, you'll want to finish with the red chocolate bun, which balances the sweetness of chocolate with a touch of pig's blood. Yep, Tea Room has just the right amount of pomp and tea ceremony in our opinion.

text.text:
Tea Room is exactly the kind of stylish and sultry spot you had in mind for date night. The retro Cantonese design complete with beautiful tiling, neon signage and a menu printed on a vintage-looking newspaper all add to the vibe of 60s Hong Kong hedonism. Grown up cocktails should lube up your convo nicely, and with all manner of curious Chinese skewers and snacks, you'll have plenty to talk about too.

The damage: upwards of £40 (for two pre booze, but cocktails can bump it up quickly).
***Great Value***

tip.text:
Forza Win is a shape shifter. What started out as a roaming pop up soon found a permanent home in a restored old grain store in Copeland Park, where it then morphed into a sumptuous set-menu affair. These days, it's a humble restaurant serving simple(ish) Italian dishes, with a modest price point to match - but don't underestimate the magic going on in the kitchen: the flavours here are devastatingly good.

Whilst the menu changes frequently, you'll always find an array of pasta dishes alongside some choice meat (and the odd veggie) mains. We slurped up tagliatelle topped with oven-blistered tomatoes that burst with sun-drenched flavours, as well as a sausage pappardelle that had the comfort factor and flavour of bangers and mash. Dessert is serious affair: opt for the custardo (a Forza Win invention - espresso topped with crème anglaise) and their deconstructed tiramisu, then prepare to nurture a food baby for the eve. Bop along on Wednesdays for their 'Awesome Sauce' deal, where you can scoop up a pasta dish and a glass of booze for a tenner.

text.text:
Forza Win serves up simple(ish) Italian dishes, with a modest price point to match - but don't underestimate the magic going on in the kitchen: the flavours here are devastatingly good. Whilst the menu changes frequently, you'll always find an array of flavoursome grilled veggies, fresh fish, hunky meats and homely pasta dishes. Finish off by sharing that plate of tiramisu -this should up the intimacy and save some cash in one deft move.

The damage: upwards of £40 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
Fresh pasta bars may not be that hard to find in London these days, but that's because they're so damn good. There's something so satisfying about watching a chef roll, stretch and cut dough in front of you, then do that satisfying flour dust thing before introducing it to that salty bath that will transform it into a perfectly al dente plate of carby goodness. Bancone is one such place, just off Trafalgar Square, that feels fancy enough for a date, but relaxed enough for a casual bite - and cheap enough for either.

We sat at the marble counter for prime pasta watching and settled in with an excellent negroni. To eat we started with a plate of smoked duck breast with charred, picked artichokes and another of chicory, sour onions and anchovy crumb: both simple and superb. For the main event we had a delightfully rich cacio e pepe and a delightfully delicate cuttlefish tagliatelle with chilli and garlic. For a refreshing finish, we'd tip the Amalfi lemon syllabub.

text.text:
Bancone feels fancy enough for a date, but relaxed enough for a casual bite - and cheap enough for either. It's one of those 'do one thing and do it well' kinda spots and that thing is fresh pasta; ideal if you wanna meet your boo half-way along a tagliatelle strand just like those dogs in that Disney movie. Their pasta has bite and their sauces are creamy, and for a refreshing finish, it's the Amalfi lemon syllabub for you.

The damage: upwards of £35 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
Escape the hordes of tourists around Piccadilly and step underground into the cavernous, gilded dining room of Brasserie Zédel where you're likely to feel like a tourist yourself - albeit one in Paris. Swot up on your GSCE French or have Google translate on standby as the menu is en Français. Classic steak frites hits the spot while after dinner it's all about the peach sorbet - and more champagne.

Also, their Prix Fixe of two courses for a tenner (or three for £13) is a legit bargain for those looking to impress on a budget.

text.text:
Affordable luxury purveyor Brasserie Zedel does a bargain prix fixe menu - which is pretty nifty considering you’re seated in one of the most beautiful restaurant interiors about and likely rubbing shoulders with celebs. Thing is, we’re not sure how romantic it is to point to a tiny box on the menu and say, 'You can have either of these two options.' So use this one at your own risk.

The damage: The Prix Fixe menu does two courses for a tenner or three for £13. Everything else is a fair bit more.

tip.text:
What’s the best thing you can do with £8? If you’ve answered, ‘go to FM Mangal on Camberwell Church Street and get the lamb shish box meal’, then you’ve got it right. FM Mangal is, for our money, the best kebabby to be found in South: a typical no-frills Turkish joint where the sweet elixir of smoking coals charring meat to perfection wafts out the door and brings in any local with an interest in good food.

The tender meat here comes with dope company: fragrant rice, fresh salad, charred flat breads, pomegranate molasses and complimentary charcoal-grilled onions in a sweet and sour vinegary sauce. Served up by a lovely staff, you’re not getting tablecloths or airs and graces; you're getting an ideal bite when you can't be arsed to cook or a venue for a lively group dine out.

text.text:
FM Mangal is your typical no-frills Turkish joint where the sweet elixir of smoking coals charring meat to perfection wafts out the door and brings in any local with an interest in good food. You may not think a kebab restaurant is the most romantic idea but the multicoloured lanterns here say different (as does the fact we've been on many a successful date here too 😉). Who can say no to warm flat breads dipped in a sauce of pomegranate molasses and sweet charred onions?

The damage: upwards of £30 (for two pre booze).
**SKINTED**

tip.text:
Let’s get it straight - this is frickin' dope pizza. Sodo were once just Clapton cult heroes but they've spread a little and their Bethnal Green joint, hidden far from the madding crowds on a quiet cobbled street in a railway arch, gives their beautifully thin, topping-heavy, sumptuous sourdough pies ample space for expression.

Keeping things strictly pizza, we came in and went in on the Lorena (tomato, mozzarella, butternut squash, feta, pine nuts and rosemary); and the Wicker Man (tomato, mozzarella, 'ndjua, pepperoni, mascarpone and scotch bonnet honey). One was sweet; one savoury - both surprised us with interesting combos of fresh ingredients that managed to keep it classic whilst also offering something fresh. The space itself, rife with plants, soft woods and supple lighting, hits the perfect note of a casual pizzeria capable of evolving into something romantic and amorous given the right occasion. An excellent pizza place to drop in on.

text.text:
Hidden far from the madding crowds on a quiet cobbled street in a railway arch, Sodo's Bethnal Green joint offers a more casual date spot while maintaining the prerequisite dim lighting, plants and easy drinking cocktails. Then there's the beautifully thin, topping-heavy, sumptuous sourdough pies that made Sodo's name. The Wicker Man (tomato, mozzarella, 'ndjua, pepperoni, mascarpone and scotch bonnet honey) is always a winner. 

The damage: upwards of £25 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
Stroll along Upper Street and let the fragrant smell of sizzling slabs of meat seduce you into this ramshackle spot, where intricate, stained-glass lanterns dangle from the ceiling, giving the restaurant a warm subdued glow. Random knick-knacks litter the wall giving your eyes plenty to ogle whilst you wait for the main attraction.

The menu is a selection of Turkish and Mediterranean goodies, from tasty meze morsels like baba ganoush, dolma, and falafel; to hunks of marinated meat on mounds of rice and salad. So sit down, pop a button, and clear your schedule for the rest of the day - this is going to be heavy.

text.text:
Upper Street's favourite ramshackle spot, Gallipoli gives your eyes plenty to ogle while you wait for the main attraction. Random knick-knacks litter the wall, while intricate, stained-glass lanterns dangle from the ceiling, giving the restaurant a warm subdued glow. The menu of Turkish and Mediterranean goodies is perfect for sharing over drinks; many a great love story was made over hummus.

The damage: upwards of £25 (for two pre booze).

tip.text:
This charming cafe is the brick-and-mortar embodiment of community spirit. Originally set up in the 80s to serve the growing squatting community in the area, it is now run by a rotating collective of chefs at prices that keep it accessible to all members of the local clientele - plus, it's BYOB, which is just fantastic.

Offerings are vegan and vegetarian. The carousel-like nature of the kitchen means you’re never 100% sure of what you’re gonna get, but you can be pretty confident that it’ll be delicious. Don't wait on this one - there have been rumours rumbling about closure due to high rents and property types sticking their beaks in.

text.text:
This charming cafe is the brick-and-mortar embodiment of community spirit. Originally set up in the 80s to serve the growing squatting community in the area, it's now run by a collective of chefs who mix veggie and vegan food, homely interiors and bargain prices. The carousel-like nature of the kitchen means you’re never 100% sure of what you’re gonna get, but you can be pretty confident that it’ll be delicious.

The damage: £18-30 (for two pre booze).

tip.text: Steak pie, thick chips, fry ups and gallons of gravy - everything you could want from a greasy spoon, right in the heart of Westminster. The Regency Cafe is definitely a bit school-cantiney in the way that one must fetch one's own breakfast from the counter, but in our opinion, that only adds to the charm. And with the old school black tiling, red and white checkered fabric and framed pictures of old Londinium, this is really a cafe of cafes.

text.text:
This may not seem like the most romantic place in the world - you probably wouldn’t book it for your three-year anniversary - but let’s say you could engineer it so you end up here after a day of gadding about; it’s a cold evening, the windows are steamy and you squeeze in to Regency Cafe for a hearty plate of ham, egg and chips then lock eyes over a warm bowl of bread-and-butter pudding. It could be one of the cutest dates you've ever been on, couldn’t it? Just make sure you get there early as it closes at 7pm.

The damage: between £10-20 (for two pre booze).
